revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox Weapon |name=Reșița 75 mm anti-gun |image=[[File:Tun 75 mm Resita Model 1943.jpg|300px]] |caption= DT-UDR 26 displayed in [[Timișoara]]. |origin=Romania |type=anti-tank gun <!-- Type selection --> |is_ranged=yes |is_artillery=yes |is_vehicle= <!-- Service history --> |service=1943—45? |used_by= [[Kingdom of Romania|Romania]] |wars= [[World War II]] <!-- Production history --> |designer= |design_date=1942—43 |manufacturer=Uzinele și Domeniile Reșița, Astra, Concordia |production_date=1944—45? |number=342+ |variants= <!-- General specifications --> |spec_label= |weight={{convert|1430|kg|lb}} |length={{convert|5.45|m|ft}} |width={{convert|1.82|m|ft}} |height={{convert|1.55|m|ft}} |part_length={{convert|2.501|m|in}} (rifling) |crew=7 <!-- Ranged weapon specifications --> |cartridge=fixed |cartridge_weight={{convert|6.6|kg|lb}} ([[Armor-piercing shot and shell|AP]]) |caliber={{convert|75|mm|in}} |action= |rate=up to 20 rounds per minute |velocity={{convert|1030|m/s|ft/s}} |range= |max_range={{convert|12000|m|yd}} ([[Explosive material|HE]]) |feed= |sights= <!-- Artillery specifications --> |breech=vertical sliding block |recoil= |carriage=split trail |elevation=-7° to +35° |traverse=70° }}
The '''75 mm Reșița Model 1943''' was an [[anti-tank gun]] produced by [[Kingdom of Romania|Romania]] during [[World War II]]. It combined features from the Soviet [[76 mm divisional gun M1942 (ZiS-3)|''ZiS-3'']] field\anti-tank gun, the German [[7.5 cm PaK 40|PaK 40]] and the Romanian ''75 mm Vickers/Reșița Model 1936'' anti-aircraft gun. It saw service against both the Soviets during the [[Jassy–Kishinev Offensive (August 1944)|Jassy-Kishniev Offensive]] and against the Germans during the [[Budapest Offensive]] and subsequent operations to clear Austria and Czechoslovakia.
==Development== Development began in 1942 of a dual-purpose field and anti-tank gun that could be built in Romania to replace the collection of obsolescent field guns currently used and upgrade their anti-tank defenses of the army. To speed development Colonel Valerian Nestorescu suggested combining the best features from the {{convert|75|mm|in}} guns already in service in Romania, Germany or captured from the Soviets. Colonel Nestorescu was selected to produce a prototype to be built at the [[Uzinele şi Domeniile Reşiţa]] in [[Reşiţa]]. Three prototypes were built combining various features and trialled against the ''ZiS-3'', a Reşiţa-built copy of the ''ZiS-3'', the ''Pak 40'' and the ''Schneider-Putilov Model 1902/36'' field gun in September 1943 and the third prototype had the greatest armor penetration. It was adopted as the ''Tunul antitanc DT-UDR 26, cal. 75 mm, md. 1943'', commonly shortened to ''75 mm Reşiţa Model 1943''.<ref>Axworthy, pp. 235-6</ref>
==Description== [[File:75mmResitaModel1943 1.JPG|thumb|left|DT-UDR 26 close-up view]] It combined the [[muzzle brake]], recoil and firing mechanisms and split-trail carriage of the ''ZiS-3'', the barrel, rifling and cartridge chamber of the ''[[Vickers Model 1931|Vickers/Reşiţa Model 1936]]'' [[anti-aircraft]] gun and the projectile chamber of the ''Pak 40''. It had a [[gun shield]] that consisted of two {{convert|6|mm|in}} plates separated by a {{convert|20|mm|in}} gap. It had only 680 parts, almost as few as the 610 of the ''ZiS-3'', but far fewer than the 1200 of the ''Pak 40''. It had a higher muzzle velocity and thus greater penetrative power than the ''Pak 40''. It therefore combined virtues of both the ''ZiS-3'' and ''Pak 40''. 1100 were ordered on 10 December 1943 from Uzinele și Domeniile Reșița, Astra in [[Braşov]] and Concordia in [[Ploieşti]].<ref>Axworthy, pp. 236-7</ref>
The ''75 mm Reșița Model 1943'' fired a {{convert|6.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} [[armor-piercing]] shell at {{convert|1030|m/s|ft/s}}. It was credited with penetration of a plate over {{convert|100|mm|in}} thick angled at 30° from the vertical at {{convert|500|m|yd}}.<ref>Axworthy, p. 235</ref> However, this high muzzle velocity came at the cost of a very short barrel life, only 500 rounds, compared to the 6000 of a ''Pak 40''. Its ammunition combined features of shells used by the ''Pak 40'' and the ''Vickers/Reșița Model 1936'' anti-aircraft gun,<ref>Axworthy, p. 236</ref> although this raises the issue of exactly how the ''Reșița Model 1943'' achieved such velocities. The ''Pak 40'' had a muzzle velocity of {{convert|990|m/s|ft/s|abbr=on}} when firing the light-weight, tungsten-cored ''Pzgr 40'' shell, but the only data for the Reșița give a shell weight of {{convert|6.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, which is roughly equivalent to the ''Pak 40'''s full-sized {{convert|6.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} ''Pzgr 39'' shell that was fired at a mere {{convert|792|m/s|ft/s}}.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hogg|first=Ian V.|title=German Artillery of World War Two|publisher=Greenhill Books|location=London|year=1997|edition=2nd corrected|page=197|isbn=1-85367-480-X}}</ref> Unfortunately detailed specifications for the Reșița's ammunition haven't been discovered so that question will have to remain unanswered.
==Operational use== [[File:75 mm Resita Model 1943 Oradea.JPG|thumb|left|Breech incriptions on the gun in Oradea, Romania. Serial number 394.]] The first twenty-four were issued to the ''1st Armored Division'' in the spring of 1944 and later two independent anti-tank regiments with thirty-six guns apiece formed from the artillery regiments of the disbanded ''Frontier Division''. Most of the cavalry and infantry divisions began to receive some guns during the summer of 1944. An estimated 342 were produced by the end of 1944. However, the gun displayed in Oradea has serial number 394, thus the production run was likely larger. Despite the losses suffered during the Soviet [[Jassy–Kishinev Offensive (August 1944)|Jassy-Kishniev Offensive]] of August 1944 most divisions at the front in February 1945 had between six and twelve ''75 mm Reșița Model 1943'' on hand.<ref>Axworthy, p. 237</ref> After the war, the gun was relegated to secondary roles, such as training, because it had a western caliber. The ''75 mm Reșița Model 1943'' was used until 1998, when it was phased out.<ref>''Army Courier'', no. 21(232) 15 November 2007, page 9</ref>
The gun was also used on the later prototypes of the [[Mareșal tank destroyer]].
One is on display today at the [[National Military Museum (Romania)|Romanian National Military Museum]] in Bucharest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muzeulmilitar.ro/colectii/47.html |title=Colectii — Specialitati militare |language=Romanian |accessdate=2009-05-21 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Another is displayed on the sidewalk in front of the Military Museum in [[Oradea]]. Two more guns are emplaced in Libertatii Square in [[Timisoara]]. A fifth gun is preserved in the [[Dej]] Military Museum.
